Name: oid
column6: row identifier (hidden attribute; must be explicitly selected)

Name: proname
column6: name of the function

Name: pronamespace
column6: the oid of the namespace that contains this function

Name: proowner
column6: owner of the function

Name: prolang
column6: implementation language or call interface of this function

Name: procost
column6: estimated execution cost (in units of cpu_operator_cost); if proretset, this is cost per row returned

Name: prorows
column6: estimated number of result rows (zero if not proretset)

Name: provariadic
column6: data type of the variadic array parameter's elements, or zero if the function does not have a variadic parameter

Name: protransform
column6: calls to this function can be simplified by this other function (see section 36.9.11)

Name: proisagg
column6: function is an aggregate function

Name: proiswindow
column6: function is a window function

Name: prosecdef
column6: function is a security definer (i.e., a "setuid" function)

Name: proleakproof
column6: the function has no side effects. no information about the arguments is conveyed except via the return value. any function that might throw an error depending on the values of its arguments is not leak-proof.

Name: proisstrict
column6: function returns null if any call argument is null. in that case the function won't actually be called at all. functions that are not "strict" must be prepared to handle null inputs.

Name: proretset
column6: function returns a set (i.e., multiple values of the specified data type)

Name: provolatile
column6: provolatile tells whether the function's result depends only on its input arguments, or is affected by outside factors. it is i for "immutable" functions, which always deliver the same result for the same inputs. it is s for "stable" functions, whose results (for fixed inputs) do not change within a scan. it is v for "volatile" functions, whose results might change at any time. (use v also for functions with side-effects, so that calls to them cannot get optimized away.)

Name: proparallel
column6: proparallel tells whether the function can be safely run in parallel mode. it is s for functions which are safe to run in parallel mode without restriction. it is r for functions which can be run in parallel mode, but their execution is restricted to the parallel group leader; parallel worker processes cannot invoke these functions. it is u for functions which are unsafe in parallel mode; the presence of such a function forces a serial execution plan.

Name: pronargs
column6: number of input arguments

Name: pronargdefaults
column6: number of arguments that have defaults

Name: prorettype
column6: data type of the return value

Name: proargtypes
column6: an array with the data types of the function arguments. this includes only input arguments (including inout and variadic arguments), and thus represents the call signature of the function.

Name: proallargtypes
column6: an array with the data types of the function arguments. this includes all arguments (including out and inout arguments); however, if all the arguments are in arguments, this field will be null. note that subscripting is 1-based, whereas for historical reasons proargtypes is subscripted from 0.

Name: proargmodes
column6: an array with the modes of the function arguments, encoded as i for in arguments, o for out arguments, b for inout arguments, v for variadic arguments, t for table arguments. if all the arguments are in arguments, this field will be null. note that subscripts correspond to positions of proallargtypes not proargtypes.

Name: proargnames
column6: an array with the names of the function arguments. arguments without a name are set to empty strings in the array. if none of the arguments have a name, this field will be null. note that subscripts correspond to positions of proallargtypes not proargtypes.

Name: proargdefaults
column6: expression trees (in nodetostring() representation) for default values. this is a list with pronargdefaults elements, corresponding to the last n input arguments (i.e., the last n proargtypes positions). if none of the arguments have defaults, this field will be null.

Name: protrftypes
column6: data type oids for which to apply transforms.

Name: prosrc
column6: this tells the function handler how to invoke the function. it might be the actual source code of the function for interpreted languages, a link symbol, a file name, or just about anything else, depending on the implementation language/call convention.

Name: probin
column6: additional information about how to invoke the function. again, the interpretation is language-specific.

Name: proconfig
column6: function's local settings for run-time configuration variables

Name: proacl
column6: access privileges; see grant and revoke for details
